explanation: The reported violation is not supported by the code shown. handle_recv_no_space itself does not call any <string.h> functions; it only forwards c->read_buffer and an explicit length (c->read_buffer_offset) to helper routines (handle_req_headers_no_space, handle_req_footers_no_space, handle_req_chunk_size_line_no_space, …). MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 prohibits uses of the <string.h> routines that can access beyond the bounds of the objects pointed to; a violation would exist only if one of the callees actually invokes a string.h routine (e.g. strlen, strcpy, strcat, memcpy, etc.) in a way that can read or write past the provided buffer/length. The scenario described by Agent A (a callee calling strlen on a non-NUL-terminated receive buffer or copying more bytes than available) is plausible, but it is speculation about the implementation of those helper functions rather than a demonstrated violation in handle_recv_no_space itself. Therefore the report that this function violates Rule 21.17 is not correct as-is. Recommendation: inspect the implementations of the called helpers and ensure they either (a) treat the data as non-string raw buffers and use length-bounded operations (memcpy/memmove/memchr/memset with explicit lengths) or (b) ensure the buffer is NUL-terminated before calling string functions or use strnlen/strncpy with appropriate length bounds. If any callee uses unbounded string functions on the raw receive buffer without checking the provided length, that callee would be the location of a Rule 21.17 violation.
